categories.title: Geriatric Syndromes
categories.description: Common clinical conditions in older adults that don't fit into discrete disease categories

topics.title: Falls and Fall Prevention
topics.content: Falls are the leading cause of injury-related deaths in adults aged 65+. Risk factors include muscle weakness, vitamin D deficiency, vision problems, medications (especially psychotropics), and environmental hazards.
keyPoints: Conduct comprehensive fall risk assessments using tools like Morse Fall Scale
Implement multifactorial interventions: exercise, medication review, vision correction
Home safety modifications: grab bars, adequate lighting, removing trip hazards
Vitamin D supplementation (800-1000 IU daily) reduces fall risk by 19%
Tai Chi and balance training reduce falls by 20-30%

topics.title: Delirium Recognition and Management
topics.content: Delirium affects up to 50% of hospitalized older adults. It's associated with increased mortality, prolonged hospitalization, and cognitive decline.
keyPoints: Use CAM (Confusion Assessment Method) for screening
Identify and treat underlying causes: infections, medications, metabolic disturbances
Non-pharmacological interventions first: reorientation, sleep hygiene, early mobilization
Avoid benzodiazepines except for alcohol withdrawal
Low-dose antipsychotics only for severe agitation posing safety risk

topics.title: Polypharmacy and Deprescribing
topics.content: Polypharmacy (≥5 medications) affects 40% of older adults and increases risk of adverse drug events, falls, and hospitalizations.
keyPoints: Regular medication reconciliation at every visit
Use STOPP/START criteria for inappropriate prescribing
Consider deprescribing when benefits no longer outweigh risks
Beers Criteria for potentially inappropriate medications
Patient-centered approach: align medications with goals of care

topics.title: Frailty Assessment and Interventions
topics.content: Frailty affects 10-15% of community-dwelling older adults and up to 50% in nursing homes. It's characterized by decreased physiologic reserve.
keyPoints: Fried Frailty Phenotype: weight loss, exhaustion, low activity, slowness, weakness
Clinical Frailty Scale for rapid assessment
Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment for frail patients
Multicomponent interventions: nutrition, exercise, social support
Frailty is potentially reversible with early intervention
topics.guidelines: International Conference on Frailty and Sarcopenia Research

categories.title: Cognitive Disorders
categories.description: Diagnosis and management of dementia and cognitive impairment

topics.title: Alzheimer's Disease: Current Management
topics.content: Alzheimer's disease accounts for 60-80% of dementia cases. Early diagnosis and comprehensive management improve quality of life.
keyPoints: Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) for mild-moderate stages
Memantine for moderate-severe stages, can combine with ChEIs
New drugs: Aducanumab and Lecanemab - controversial efficacy
Non-pharmacological interventions: cognitive stimulation, exercise, music therapy
Caregiver support and education crucial for outcomes

topics.title: Vascular Dementia Prevention and Management
topics.content: Second most common dementia type, often coexists with Alzheimer's. Focus on vascular risk factor modification.
keyPoints: Aggressive blood pressure control (<130/80 mmHg)
Antiplatelet therapy for stroke prevention
Statin therapy for dyslipidemia
Diabetes management with HbA1c <7%
No specific medications approved; manage symptoms

topics.title: Lewy Body Dementia: Recognition and Treatment
topics.content: Third most common dementia, characterized by fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism.
keyPoints: Core features: fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, REM sleep behavior disorder, parkinsonism
Severe neuroleptic sensitivity - avoid typical antipsychotics
Rivastigmine may help cognition and hallucinations
Quetiapine or clozapine for psychosis if needed
Melatonin for REM sleep behavior disorder

categories.title: Geriatric Pharmacology
categories.description: Safe prescribing practices for older adults

topics.title: Age-Related Pharmacokinetic Changes
topics.content: Aging affects drug absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion, requiring dose adjustments.
keyPoints: Decreased renal function: use Cockcroft-Gault or CKD-EPI for dosing
Reduced hepatic metabolism: lower doses of hepatically cleared drugs
Increased fat:lean ratio affects drug distribution
Decreased albumin increases free drug levels
Start low, go slow principle for dose titration

topics.title: Pain Management in Older Adults
topics.content: Chronic pain affects 50% of community-dwelling and 80% of nursing home residents.
keyPoints: Acetaminophen first-line, max 3g/day (2g if liver disease)
Avoid NSAIDs if possible; use shortest duration, lowest dose
Topical agents for localized pain (capsaicin, lidocaine, diclofenac)
Opioids: start with short-acting, avoid meperidine and propoxyphene
Multimodal approach: physical therapy, CBT, acupuncture

topics.title: Anticoagulation in the Elderly
topics.content: Balancing stroke prevention with bleeding risk in atrial fibrillation and VTE.
keyPoints: DOACs preferred over warfarin for most indications
Dose adjustments based on renal function, weight, age
Fall risk alone not contraindication if CHA2DS2-VASc ≥3
Regular reassessment of risks vs benefits
Reversal agents: idarucizumab (dabigatran), andexanet alfa (Xa inhibitors)

categories.title: Preventive Care and Screening
categories.description: Evidence-based screening and prevention for older adults

topics.title: Cancer Screening in Older Adults
topics.content: Individualized approach based on life expectancy, functional status, and patient preferences.
keyPoints: Breast cancer: mammography to age 74, then individualized
Colorectal: screen to age 75, selective 76-85, stop after 85
Cervical: stop at 65 if adequate prior screening
Prostate: shared decision-making, consider stopping at 70
Lung: annual CT for smokers 50-80 with 20 pack-year history

topics.title: Immunizations for Older Adults
topics.content: Vaccines are crucial for preventing morbidity and mortality in older adults.
keyPoints: Influenza: high-dose or adjuvanted vaccine annually
Pneumococcal: PCV20 or PCV15 followed by PPSV23
Herpes zoster: Shingrix (2 doses) for all ≥50 years
COVID-19: stay up-to-date with boosters
Tdap: once, then Td every 10 years

topics.title: Osteoporosis Screening and Treatment
topics.content: Osteoporosis affects 25% of women and 5% of men over 65, leading to fractures.
keyPoints: DEXA screening: women ≥65, men ≥70, younger if risk factors
FRAX tool for 10-year fracture risk assessment
Calcium 1200mg and Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily
Bisphosphonates first-line, consider drug holiday after 5 years
Denosumab, teriparatide for severe osteoporosis

categories.title: Palliative and End-of-Life Care
categories.description: Compassionate care for serious illness and end of life

topics.title: Advance Care Planning Conversations
topics.content: Early discussions about goals, values, and preferences improve end-of-life care quality.
keyPoints: Start conversations early when cognitive capacity intact
Use SPIKES protocol for difficult conversations
Document in advance directives: living will, healthcare proxy
POLST/MOLST for seriously ill patients
Regular reassessment as health status changes

topics.title: Symptom Management at End of Life
topics.content: Addressing pain, dyspnea, anxiety, and other symptoms in final days.
keyPoints: Pain: morphine gold standard, use breakthrough doses
Dyspnea: opioids effective, oxygen only if hypoxemic
Delirium: haloperidol for hyperactive, supportive care
Secretions: repositioning, glycopyrrolate, avoid suctioning
Anxiety: lorazepam sublingual or subcutaneous

topics.title: Hospice Referral and Eligibility
topics.content: Hospice improves quality of life and may extend survival in some conditions.
keyPoints: Prognosis ≤6 months if disease follows expected course
Disease-specific criteria: cancer, dementia, heart failure, COPD
General indicators: functional decline, weight loss, infections
Can continue disease-modifying therapy if comfort-focused
Family satisfaction higher with earlier referral

categories.title: Functional and Social Assessment
categories.description: Comprehensive evaluation of function and social determinants

topics.title: ADL and IADL Assessment Tools
topics.content: Functional assessment predicts outcomes and guides care planning.
keyPoints: Katz ADL: bathing, dressing, toileting, transferring, continence, feeding
Lawton IADL: shopping, housework, finances, medications, phone, transport
Performance-based: Timed Up and Go, gait speed, grip strength
Functional decline often first sign of illness
Regular reassessment to track changes

topics.title: Social Isolation and Loneliness
topics.content: Social isolation increases mortality risk equivalent to smoking 15 cigarettes daily.
keyPoints: Screen with UCLA Loneliness Scale or single question
Risk factors: living alone, mobility limitations, sensory impairment
Health impacts: depression, cognitive decline, cardiovascular disease
Interventions: social prescribing, technology training, group activities
Community resources: senior centers, volunteer programs

topics.title: Caregiver Burden and Support
topics.content: Family caregivers provide 80% of long-term care but often experience burnout.
keyPoints: Zarit Burden Interview for assessment
Signs: depression, anxiety, physical health decline
Respite care crucial for caregiver wellbeing
Education about disease process and resources
Support groups and counseling services
